newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan mulls expanding ship link plan with China.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan mulls expanding ship link plan with China.

text.p: Taiwan's communications ministry said on Monday it was considering expanding its plan for direct shipping links with China, in a bid to attract more foreign firms to join its Asia-Pacific operation centre plan.
Many shipping firms hoped to extend their routes after they could sail between China and Taiwan, said Hsieh Ming-hui, head of the ministry's navigation and aviation unit.
"We are considering the proposal, but it needs final approval by the cabinet to take effect," Hsueh said.

Last year Taiwan proposed setting up an offshore trans-shipment centre at southern Kaohsiung port from where ships would be allowed to sail directly between Taiwan and China. The project has been delayed by sovereignty issues.

The current planned rules would allow only feeder service by foreign ships and foreign-registered, Taiwanese-owned ships to sail between Taiwan and China, but would forbid them from extending the routes to other areas, Hsueh said.
"The proposal will also apply to foreign mother vessels, expanding the business for foreign vessels and foreign-registered but Taiwanese-owned vessels," Hsieh said.
Taiwan has banned direct air and shipping links with China since Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists lost the civil war to the Chinese communists and fled to the island in 1949.

On August 20, China unveiled rules governing direct shipping links across the Taiwan strait, effective immediately, but Taiwan responded coolly, saying Beijing's rules were "mingled with sensitive political issues".
